[[Evolutionary psychology|Evolutionary psychologists]] often argue that human morality is necessary for survival. An innate sense of right and wrong allows a thinking species to have cohesion, helping the society and its members to thrive. Selected behaviours, seen in abstraction as [[moral code]]s, are common to all human cultures, and reflect, in their development, similarities to [[natural selection]]. This aspect of morality can be seen as incarnated in [[religion|religious]] doctrine, much of which deals with the acceptance, in people, of positive aspects, and the rejection of negative ones. Thus it can be argued that there is a [[Darwinian]] [[memetic]] explanation for the existence of religion: regardless of the truth or falsity of religious beliefs, religion tends to encourage morality, morality tends to encourage communality, and communality tends to assist survival.
